unnormalised: The first time I filled up my scooter after moving to Bangalore, I was utterly confused. Back home, we always talked about fuel in liters, but here, everyone seemed to be obsessed with mileage, expressed in kmpl. It was like learning a new language, one where efficiency was king. My old scooter, bless its heart, probably gave me around 35 kmpl on a good day, a figure I was deeply ashamed to admit to my new colleagues.
normalised: the first time i filled up my scooter after moving to bangalore, i was utterly confused. back home, we always talked about fuel in liters, but here, everyone seemed to be obsessed with mileage, expressed in kilometer per liter. it was like learning a new language, one where efficiency was king. my old scooter, bless its heart, probably gave me around thirty five kilometer per liter on a good day, a figure i was deeply ashamed to admit to my new colleagues.

unnormalised: My roommate, Rajesh, a true Bangalore veteran, immediately took pity on my ignorance. “Arre, you have to understand the traffic,” he said, sipping his chai. “It’s all about stop-start. Nobody gets the mileage they claim in the ads. Expect around 30 kmpl in the city, maybe 40 kmpl on the highway.” He went on to describe his own bike, a sleek Royal Enfield, boasting a fuel tank capacity of 13.5 Liters.

unnormalised: I spent the next few weeks meticulously tracking my fuel consumption. Every time I visited the petrol pump, I'd note down the amount of fuel I poured in, and the distance I had covered since the last fill-up. I meticulously calculated my scooter's average, which, to my dismay, hovered around 28 kmpl. Evenings were spent on Google, frantically searching for tips to improve fuel efficiency. I tried everything from maintaining a steady speed to ensuring the tyres were properly inflated – the recommended pressure being 28 PSI at the front and 32 PSI at the back.

unnormalised: One day, after a particularly frustrating commute, I decided to try a different petrol station. The attendant, a kindly old man, suggested I use a higher octane fuel, claiming it would improve my scooter's performance. He filled my tank with 5 liters of the premium stuff, costing me an extra Rs. 20 per liter. I was skeptical, but willing to try anything.

unnormalised: To my surprise, the higher octane fuel seemed to make a difference. My scooter felt more responsive, and the mileage improved slightly, creeping up to around 32 kmpl. It wasn't a dramatic change, but it was enough to justify the extra expense. Rajesh, however, remained unconvinced, arguing that it was all in my head. He insisted on sticking to regular petrol, which cost around Rs. 100 per liter at the time.

unnormalised: Eventually, I learned to accept my scooter's fuel efficiency for what it was. Bangalore traffic was simply too brutal to expect anything more. I stopped obsessing over kmpl and started focusing on enjoying the ride, even if it meant visiting the petrol pump a little more often. After all, as Rajesh always said, "Thoda petrol zyada lagega, but life toh jeeni hai!"
